user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_FileOpenCheck:
```c
int32 OS_FileOpenCheck(const char *Filename)
{
    int32                        return_code;
    OS_object_iter_t             iter;
    OS_stream_internal_record_t *stream;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(Filename);

    return_code = OS_ERROR;

    OS_ObjectIdIterateActive(LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, &iter);

    while (OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(&iter))
    {
        stream = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_stream_table, iter.token);
        if (stream->socket_domain == OS_SocketDomain_INVALID && (strcmp(stream->stream_name, Filename) == 0))
        {
            return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
            break;
        }
    }

    OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy(&iter);

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Only the code fragments that invoke Standard Library string handling functions need investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. In this function the only use of a <string.h> function is the strcmp call inside the shown if statement — therefore it is reported. Other lines and constructs are not relevant to this rule: OS_CHECK_POINTER(Filename) is a pointer-validation macro (not a string library call); the iterator setup, OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext, OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy, and OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET calls manipulate object/iterator state and do not call string.h functions; the remaining variable declarations, assignments, and return statements do not involve string handling. No other <string.h> functions (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn, etc.) appear in this code fragment, so they do not need investigation here.
